section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we make things go?

section-block.rac_book_summary: Oscar, a curious kitten, learns about push and pull forces while having fun with a ball. Cricket answers Oscar’s questions as he notices many things that move.

section-block.rac_body-text: Sing “The Wheels on the Bus” with children. The wheels on the bus go round and round; wipers . . . go swish, swish, swish; doors . . . open and close.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Oscar and the Cricket, written by Geoff Waring.
Pablo loves this narrative. He thinks it’s a great story that also explains how some things move.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What does Oscar make the ball do?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Oscar do to the ball?
What word that begins with /r/ tells how the ball moved?
Which surface is smoother—the grass or the path? Why does the the ball roll farther on the path?
What makes the leaves move? What else can the wind move?
How do elephants use their muscles to move things? Does the spider monkey have strong muscles? How do you know?
Why does the ball roll so much farther this time?
What are two ways this story shows how things get moving? Which force does Oscar use to make the ball move? Which force does he use to move the branch?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What does Oscar make the ball do?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about how things can move, as children listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Oscar make the ball roll?
What can make a ball change direction?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Teaching science to young children instills a love of science and encourages critical thinking. Tapping into and encouraging young children’s natural curiosity about the world will help prepare them for a future in which many jobs will require science, technology, engineering, and mathematics skills.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Show Curiosity
section-block.rac_body-text: Say: What can you do if you don’t understand something, or if you want to learn more about something? You can ask “why” questions! By asking “why” questions, you look for answers and learn new things. Who remembers the “why” question that Oscar asked about the ball? Listen for “why” questions during the close-read.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look for the ask “why?” Mind Builder as we revisit the book Oscar and the Cricket by Geoff Waring.

This narrative is about how things move and roll. Clifford loves this book because it explains why things move fast or slow or change direction. Clifford is curious and likes to learn new things from books like this!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s think about the Mind Builder as we reread and ask “why?”
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What question does Oscar ask? Why do you think his is curious about the ball? Do you think he’s seen a ball before? (MB)
What “why” question does Oscar ask? What’s the answer? (MB)
How does Oscar move the branch? How is that different from how he moved the ball?
When Oscar and Cricket watch the leaves, what does Oscar think makes them move?
Why do you think Cricket tells Oscar about the different ways animals can move things?
What’s one thing you move by pushing it? What’s one thing you pull to move it?

section.rac_body-text: Explain to children that they will use force to move balls across the table. Have students sit across from each other. How can you make the ball move across the table? Guide children to answer that they can push or pull the balls. Now, think about how you can push the balls without touching them. If children don’t come up with the idea of blowing the balls across the table, explain the game. Now we are going to make our own wind by blowing a ball across the table to our partners. Then your partner will blow the ball back to you. Now show me how you can go and be ready for the writing activity. (MB)
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about how we can make things move.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Curious children ask “why?” to help make sense of the world around them. Educators aim to encourage “why” questions to represent deeper cognitive thinking. One method is to model asking “why” during read alouds. When appropriate, turn questions around to children by asking, “Why do YOU think…”

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S INVESTIGATE | WEEK 4: Make It Move

section-block.rac_body-text: Whisper either push or pull to a child. The child then chooses an object and follows the direction. Ask the class whether the child pushed or pulled something. Repeat.
Tune: “Row, Row, Row Your Boat” Push, push, push your cart/Gently through the store./Fill it up with what you need/Then push it out the door.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Oscar and the Cricket by Geoff Waring.
The story is make-believe because animals don’t talk. But it also teaches something. Pablo likes reading stories that we can learn from.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
How do you know that Oscar gave the ball a great BIG push the last time?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Read-Aloud: Focus on Push and Pull
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you think would have happened if Oscar had pushed the ball harder?
Why doesn’t Cricket think he can move the branch? If you had to move a branch, which kind of force would you use—pushing or pulling? Why? (MB)

rac_teacher-talk_blue.rac_teacher-talk_emphasis_non-ital: How does jumping make Cricket change shape?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Cricket’s muscles help him jump. What are some ways your muscles help you move?
What are the different dotted white lines showing us on this page?
What do you think the author of this book wanted to teach readers?
Did you pay close attention to what happens when Oscar pushes the ball again? Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
How do you know that Oscar gave the ball a great BIG push the last time?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share.
Possible responses:
Share a pen with children as you work together to talk and write about the different things they push and pull each day.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Did the ball keep rolling through the mud?
The ball kept rolling through m_____ (mud).
The ball kept rolling through mud.
If Ted hadn’t stopped the ball, would it ever stop?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Teaching key story words is essential for multilingual learners and is beneficial for all children. Each Vocabulary Card includes an Act It Out step to help ensure understanding of the word’s meaning. Because of its nonverbal application, this feature is particularly helpful to children with limited English proficiency.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead a discussion about how we can move things. What are some other words for push and pull? (shove, nudge, yank, tug, drag)
Talk about what a folktale is and how many different cultures have their own folktales. Invite children to give examples of other folktales they have read.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read the poster The Great Big Enormous Yuca. We’ll use the pictures and the words below them to talk about the story.

Pablo loves this story because it is how he learned that yuca is a vegetable that grows underground, like carrots. Listen for how the characters in the story try to use force to move the great, big, enormous yuca!
Oscar and the Cricket and The Great Big Enormous Yuca are about using force to make things move. Listen for how these stories are alike and how they are different.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Oscar and the Cricket book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it helps us answer the concept question:
How can we make things go?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Make It Move
section.rac_body-text: Share the poster with children. Read the Big Chart aloud. Then use these prompts to read and discuss the poster.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: The old man pulled and pulled.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The pictures and the words below tell the same story I just read, but is illustrated and has fewer words. It has all the important details.

Let’s look at the pictures and read the sentences in the same way we read and write—top to bottom and left to right. Run your finger below the words as I read. What force did the man use? What is he trying to pull?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: The enormous yuca finally came up!
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does the picture tell you about how they finally got the enormous yuca out of the ground?

section.rac_body-text: Have children work in groups of five to act out the story as you reread it. Assign the roles of the old man, the old woman, Ana, the dog, and the mouse. Remind children to be gentle when they pretend to pull on each other. Demonstrate how they can use facial expressions and sound effects to imitate pulling hard. Then have children practice their transition to their writing activity. (MB)
Provide a writing prompt about games children play that include pushing or pulling.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Folktales are powerful tools through which children can learn about different cultures and traditions. Because their simple plotlines are easy to follow, remember, and retell, folktales help develop children’s reading fluency, vocabulary, and comprehension skills. They also model two important development skills—decision-making and conflict resolution.

section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did Oscar in Oscar and the Cricket push? Let’s pretend to be Oscar the first time he sees the red ball. He doesn’t know what it is, so he has a curious look on his face.
section-block.rac_body-text: Model making a curious expression. Then have children pretend to be Oscar as he pushes the ball. What part of your body would you use to push a ball? How would you push it gently? How would you push it with more force?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and act out the story of Oscar and the Cricket by Geoff Waring.
This book is a narrative. Pablo loves to read narratives because he can learn about real things even in a made-up story.
This week, we read about what makes things move. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
What does Oscar learn about moving and rolling?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can pretend to be Oscar when he sniffs and nudges the ball?
section.rac_body-text: Invite a child to act out the part.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Oscar groaned when he pulled the heavy branch. Why do you think he did? Let’s pretend to pull something very heavy. (MB)
What makes the leaves move? Let’s pretend to be leaves on a tree. First, pretend there is no wind. What should you do? Stay very still! Now, here comes the wind. Start swaying and fluttering!
Who can use their muscles to move just one finger? One arm? Now move your whole body!
Can you jump like Cricket? Let’s all try!
I will roll the ball so that it is heading toward you. Pretend you are Ted and put out your “paw” to stop it, just like Ted did. Then push the ball back to me!

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Oscar learn about moving and rolling?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Things roll farther on smooth surfaces.
People and animals have muscles to move their bodies.
The harder you push a ball, the longer it will roll.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about how things move and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do things roll farther on a smooth surface?
Things roll farther on a sm____ (smooth) surface.
Things roll farther on a smooth surface.
Can you name two smooth surfaces and two bumpy surfaces?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Research has shown that reading aloud alone isn’t what’s most important; it’s the way a story is read aloud multiple times. The first read aloud is for enjoyment; the second, to build on children’s comprehension; and the third, to guide children in retelling the story.
